messageBody:
RE: [junit] passing arguments to TestRunner?

Andy Kriger writes:
>
> I want to load a text file that contains data to test. Currently, I
> have static ArrayLists in my TestCase class. In the setUp method, I
> check if those ArrayLists are null, and if they are, load the test
> data. So, I only load the test data once but it seems messy to have
> test data loaded for the whole suite in a method intended to setup a
> single test method. I guess this data loading can be moved to the
> suite() method?

As the suite() method only gets invoked once per test class, this would be a place you could do it. If you do so, you'll have to manage the test-suite yourself, however; the automatic discovery of tests via reflection will no longer work.

 
> However, I still have to hardcode the name of the data file. The
> TestCase class has a main method and I tried passing the test file
> name as an argument to that however that simply runs TestRunner
> which creates a new instance of the TestCase and undoes my data
> loading. Is there a way to pass the name of the data file as an
> argument to TestRunner so it can be loaded when TestRunner calls
> suite()?

Not in this version.
 
> If not, I guess I'm looking for a setUp method for suites as well as
> test methods.

We implemented such a utility at my last place of employment. In hindsight, while it was fun and interesting, I consider the solution we used as overkill (but then, we had a lot of time on our hands).

What I'd suggest, with the benefit of hindsight, is a Singleton-like pattern. Provide a utility class (possibly an inner class of the test class) which provides static methods for obtaining your data. The first time that the methods are called (or via a static initialisor, if you prefer), read your data in, and cache it for future requests.

If you are worried about hard-coding the name of the data file, don't be; for your automated tests, you'll want the data in a known location. If you want some configurability over the test, you can always store the location of the data file in a properties file.

If you're going to be using a known location for your automated test, but you want to be able to override it (say, you've got a data file that reproduces a problem and you want to look into it), I'd suggest writing a main() method in your test class that configures the Singleton object. If you invoke the test case manually, you'll be able to provide the location. If you invoke it via JUnit or via another suite(), you won't.

Robert.
